repnme.cdata!:
Mali - Second Health, Population and Rural
            Water Supply Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome was satisfactory.
            The project met all its objectives, contributed to a
            structural health sector reform, and, was successful in
            terms of institutional building for the health sector
            Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs), and local
            communities. The key lessons showed that: 1) project outcome
            must not only be measured in terms of immediate health
            indicators, but rather on the structural contribution
            towards the long-term health sector reform benefits; hence,
            the successful transition from a project, to an inclusive
            program approach. Within a reform context, the success of a
            project lies on its support to reform, reinforcing the
            government's own involvement in all sectors. Therefore,
            established legal and regulatory frameworks, are essential
            in decentralizing health care services; 2) a national health
            policy aimed at decentralization of communal health care
            services, must ensure these communities to be trained and
            able to manage their health centers. Human resources and
            institutional capacity need to be evaluated early, with
            measurable indicators; 3) local community participation
            should be ensured; to this end, the creation of a transitory
            entity succeeded, and set the basis for an initial support
            in community health management; 4) decentralization requires
            strong NGOs to support its process, and strengthen communal
            solidarity and capacity; and, 5) effective donor
            coordination lies on government ownership and leadership.

repnme.cdata!:
Mali - Second Health, Population and Rural
            Water Supply Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project objectives are to improve
            the health status and well-being of the Malian population,
            notably women and children, implement its emerging
            population policy, and broaden access of deprived rural
            communities to health services and safe water. To attain
            these objectives, the project comprises three components.
            The health component will increase the coverage and quality
            of health care: (a) directly through the development of a
            decentralized, district-based health development program
            involving the construction/rehabilitation of primary and
            referral care centers, as well as active community,
            nongovernmental organizations and private sector
            participation; and (b) indirectly by improving the planning
            and management of the sector's personnel, physical and
            financial resources as well as the provision of essential
            drugs. The population component will: (a) strengthen the
            institutions in charge of disseminating/implementing the
            national population policy and of planning, managing and
            evaluating family planning (FP) programs; and (b) increase
            the demand for, availablity and quality of FP services
            nationwide. The rural water supply component will: (a)
            increase the supply of safe drinking water for the rural
            population in the project area; (b) support the
            government's policy of community participation in the
            financial and technical management of rural water supply;
            and (c) implement an iodination program in areas where
            iodine deficiency is prevalent.
